sect2.title: Panel Items
sect2.para: GNOME &version; has had a significant focus on panel items (sometimes referred to as applets). Many panel applications have been rewritten in order to fully leverage new technology on the desktop, as well as give tighter integration with the rest of the desktop.
Most applets now support the transparent panel setting that has been available in GNOME for a long time. Allowing users to be able to have transparent, or translucent panels.

sect3.title: Integrated Modem Control
sect3.para: A new applet for controlling your Modem debuts in GNOME &version;. This monitor integrates with GNOME System Tools to give you a unified method for controlling and monitoring the state of your Modem.

sect3.title: Panel Trashcan
sect3.para: Oft requested, GNOME &version; features an optional trashcan for your Panel. Just like the trashcan on your desktop, you can drag and drop onto the trash to remove files and do other actions. Clicking on the trashcan will allow you to view deleted items in Nautilus, or you can simply empty your trash from the Panel.

sect3.title: Control Mounted Volumes
sect3.para: In the age of removable, easy to use digital media, we are constantly adding and removing volumes from our computer systems. The volume mounter applet can help. Integrating into GNOME-VFS, the same interface that Nautilus uses to mount and unmount volumes. This application shows you the current user mountable (or unmountable) volumes, allowing you to mount them, eject them or open them in Nautilus. It is the perfect compliment to Nautilus and the GNOME Volume Manager.

sect3.title: Get even more weather
sect3.para: The weather monitor has even more locations then ever before, and our team of localisers have worked hard to clean up the weather locations available in your area. In addition to this, we have improved the collection of weather information and added new weather information, including sunrise and sunset calculations for most of our locations.

sect3.title: Sound control
sect3.para: A new mixer for your panel (combined with a new look mixer on the desktop) leaverages the most out of your sound hardware. Using the GStreamer multimedia framework (the same framework that powers Totem, Sound Juicer, the GNOME CD player and a pantheon of third party applications), the mixer is now more flexible and stable then ever before. Additionally, like many programs in GNOME &version; the look of the mixer is entirely themable via the GNOME icon theme.

sect3.title: Taking note
sect3.para: The ever popular stickynote program, that leaves PostIt style notes on your desktop has been improved to offer new features and become aware of your different workspaces. Now if you have multiple workspaces, your stickynotes will stay where they belong.

Stickynotes now also act slightly differently from before. Stickynotes now remain on top of the desktop so that you can't lose them. To hide the notes, simply click on the icon and select to hide the stickynotes. Now your stickynotes will always be where you expect them.

sect3.title: Especially for laptops
sect3.para: GNOME now includes something to monitor the speed of your laptop CPU. The CPU Frequency Monitor talks to frequency scalable processers (like those with Intel Speedstep) to find out how fast they are currently running. It also offers a selection of speeds for you to choose between if you don't have automatic frequency scaling enabled.

sect2.para: Some applets have gone away in GNOME &version; because they have either been replaced by something better, or were unmainted and insecure. The three applets to be removed are, the CD Player applet, the standalone wireless monitor and mailbox check applet.

The CD Player panel applet did not interoperate well with GNOME CD Player, instead now inserting a CD will start GNOME CD Player automatically, it can then be controlled from the user interface or from a notification icon that is placed in your Panel.
The standalone wireless applet has now been superseeded by GNOME Netstatus, which has had wireless support since GNOME 2.8.

The mailbox monitor has been removed because it was unmaintained and insecure. We hope to have an solution integrated with Evolution in the future. If you don't use Evolution for your mail, you can use a third party application such as mailnotify.
